list_page_teaser: American Presidents, just like any other group of individuals, have different personalities.  Learn how the images of some popular and recent presidents reflect their idealism, decisiveness, and other qualities.
description_html:
Which politicians – ☺ if any ☺ – are your favorites? How does your personality compare to theirs?

This gallery contains a few spiritual portraits of our presidents from the 1900s. If you know your four-letter type, perhaps you can see similarities between your personality and that of your favorite president — assuming you have one!
story_html:
I frequently wonder whether an individual's personality type has any bearing on how they lean politically. As an idealist, I am definitely biased toward idealistic presidents, such as Jefferson and Lincoln.

If this topic interests you, check out David Keirsey's book Presidential Temperament. It covers this topic in depth!

I will be adding portraits to this gallery soon. To keep up to date and learn when I post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Richard Milhous Nixon
image_list.subtitle_html: 37th President of the USA — Jan. 20, 1969 to Aug. 9, 1974
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Richard Nixon's spiritual portrait shows he is very logical and a bit pragmatic.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in Richard Nixon's spiritual portrait represents his dominant personality trait, his strong preference for making logical rather than emotional decisions.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this preference in the Nixon Doctrine, which assured allies the US would honor its treaties and provide a nuclear shield, while addressing both waning support for the Vietnam War in the US and budget concerns about similar costly endeavors in other countries.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in Richard Nixon's spiritual portrait represents his auxiliary personality trait, his fairly strong preference for seeing a world of facts rather than ideas.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this preference in the way he adopted a more realistic, pragmatic view of the war in Vietnam than many of his predecessors did.
image_list.story_intro_html:
Born in Yorba Linda, California on January 9, 1913, Richard Milhous Nixon became the 37th President at the age of 56 in 1969. Even though Nixon was born two years after Ronald Reagan, he became president over a decade before Reagan.

Eisenhower's VP, and Frustrated Candidate

Before being elected President in 1968, Richard Nixon served two terms as Vice President for Dwight D. Eisenhower from 1953 to 1961. Entering office as the 36th Vice President at the age of 40, Nixon was the second-youngest person to hold that office, the youngest being John C. Breckinridge, who took the office at age 36.

Nixon lost the very close presidential election in 1960, and lost again when he ran for governor of California in 1962, and subsequently announced he was leaving politics.

As the large amounts of Green in their spiritual portraits show, Presidents Nixon and Regan were similar in many ways. And as the other colors show — Nixon's Yellow and Reagan's Blue in particular — they were a bit different in others.

Anti-Communist, and Law-and-Order Candidate

After serving in the Navy during World War II, Nixon was caught up in the anti-communist fervor that prevailed in the United States in the late 1940s and early 1950s. He was a member of the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC) and his anti-communist stance, plus his young age and political base in California, helped influence Eisenhower to choose Nixon as his running mate in the in 1952.

In 1969, Richard Nixon was President during the anti-Vietnam War demonstrations. Like his fellow Republican Ronald Reagan, Nixon leveraged this distruption by campaigning as a law-and-order candidate.

Peacemaker

Richard Nixon's anti-communist, law-and-order stance does not imply he was an enemy of peace.

As the Green in his spiritual portrait shows, Richard Nixon preferred logic to emotion. So although both he and the protesters wanted peace, he simply differed from them in that he was not inclined to get all emotional about it.

What kind of nation we will be, what kind of world we will live in, whether we shape the future in the image of our hopes, is ours to determine by our actions and our choices. The greatest honor history can bestow is the title of peacemaker.
 — Richard Nixon in his First Inaugural Address, January 20, 1969.

The sentence ending this quote — The greatest honor history can bestow is the title of peacemaker — has been memorialized as Nixon's epitaph.

Crisis: Watergate

In the presidential election of 1972, Richard Nixon carried all but one state. Like many two-term presidents, he fell prey to the second-term curse, a superstition that may betray a tendency towards confirmation bias, but proved to be very real in Nixon's case.

Shortly after the start of his second term, the Watergate scandal broke. Unbeknownst to Nixon, people in his administration were committing criminal acts, including the breaking into the offices of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist and the Democratic National Committee's.

As the Yellow in Richard Nixon's spiritual portrait shows, he is more pragmatic than idealistic. In this case, his pragmatism contributed to his downfall.

When Pragmatism Goes Wrong

Rather than do the right thing and come clean, when Richard Nixon first learned about these crimes, he tried to cover them up. But one thing led to another, and he found himself caught in his own web of deceit.

In Nixon's mind — at least initially — both sides were guilty of shady tactics, and he was doing the right thing by standing by the people who worked for him.

I know that it can be very easy, under the intensive pressures of a campaign, for even well-intentioned people to fall into shady tactics — to rationalize this on the grounds that what is at stake is of such importance to the Nation that the end justifies the means. And both of our great parties have been guilty of such tactics in the past.
 — From Richard Nixon's Address to the Nation About the Watergate Investigations, April 30, 1973.

Not a Crook

Although Nixon personally did not know about these specific activities until after the fact, his actions led to Watergate Special Counsel Archibald Cox subpeonaing tape recordings from the White House, in an effort to find out who was guilty.

Faced with rapidly declining popularity, Nixon addressed the nation with his infamous claim, I'm not a crook:

I want to say this to the television audience. I made my mistakes, but in all of my years of public life, I have never profited, never profited from public service. I have earned every cent. And in all of my years of public life, I have never obstructed justice. And I think, too, that I can say that in my years of public life, that I welcome this kind of examination because people have got to know whether or not their President is a crook. Well, I'm not a crook. I've earned everything I've got.
 — From Richard Nixon's televised address to the people of the United States, broadcast on National Public Radio, November 17, 1973.

Although Richard Nixon was willing to use politically shady tactics, he was not totally bereft of morality. His pragmatism may have contributed to his downfall, but he did his best to maintain some sense of personal honor.

Ending the War in Vietnam

In the Nixon Doctrine the President set forth in 1969, he called for Vietnamization of the region. Nixon hoped that by using troops from the South Vietnamese Army (ARVN) he could end America's involvement in the region.

In both of his terms as president, Richard Nixon worked with Henry Kissinger, his National Security Advisor, on a number of fronts to end America's involvement in the Vietnam War. Specifically they:

  • Used diplomacy by supporting the Paris Accords started in 1968 by then-President Lyndon Johnson.
  • Used the Air Force to carpet bomb Vietnam's neighbor Cambodia in 1969-1970 and North Vietnam itself from May through October of 1972, culminating in the Christmas Bombings in late December of 1972.
  • Even tried using a bit of implied irrationality to scare the communist-supported North Vietnamese into giving up.

The Paris Peace Accords included North Vietnam, South Vietnam, and South Vietnam's underground government, but encountered frequent stalemates.

In a speech Nixon gave upon being reelected in 1972, he uses the word peace six times in a single sentence:

We are united Americans — North, East, West, and South, both parties — in our desire for peace, peace with honor, the kind of a peace that will last, and we are moving swiftly toward that great goal, not just in Vietnam, but a new era of peace in which the old relationships between the two super powers, the Soviet Union and the United States, and between the world's most populous nation, the People's Republic of China, and the United States, are changed so that we are on the eve of what could be the greatest generation of peace, true peace for the whole world, that man has ever known.
 — From Richard Nixon's Remarks on Being Reelected to the Presidency, November 7, 1972. [Emphasis added.]

Nixon's Part: Logic and Facts

A president who calls for peace while ordering the Air Force to run bombing missions seems enigmatic. In calling for peace with honor, Richard Nixon makes it obvious he disagreed with Benjamin Franklin's sentiment, expressed in a Letter to Josiah Quincy dated September 11, 1783, that There never was a good war or a bad peace.

Agreeing to peace at any cost — certainly a temptation, given the ongoing and intensifying anti-war protests — was not possible, because it might imply a willingness to force South Vietnam to submit to North Vietnamese aggression.

If Nixon was going to call for peace, it would be a peace on his terms — terms that would not compromise his patriotic ideals or pose any risks to any of the freedoms Americans had grown accustomed to over the nation's past 200+ years.

As Nixon's attempts to help the opposing sides reach agreement stalled, he ordered increases in the bombings.

Nixon's part in this was to:

  • engage in peace talks
  • drop bombs to help ensure a willingness to talk

A Mixed Legacy

Ended the Vietnam War.

On February 6, 1974 the House of Representatives decided Nixon's role in covering up the malfeasance was enough for them to initiate impeachment proceedings against him. Rather than go through the impeachment process, Nixon gave his resignation speech on August 8, 1974, and left office at noon the next day.
